1508923-a.folder: Sixth Avenue - 8th Street, east side - looking south, Manhattan, NY
1508923-a.title: Sixth Avenue - 8th Street, east side - looking south

709319f-a.text:
(1)
Sixth Ave., west side, south from West 8th Street, as seen thru clearance on the east side. Also shown is a portion of the 8th Street Station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line.
June S, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same; a limited view, to and including Waverly Place.
June 5, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

709319f-b.text:
(1)
Sixth Ave., west side, south from West 8th Street, as seen thru clearance on the east side. Also shown is a portion of the 8th Street Station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line.

(2)
The same; a limited view, to and including Waverly Place.
June 5, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

709320f-a.text:
(1)
Sixth Ave.. at the convergence of Greenwich Ave. (foreground) and Christopher Street on the west side of same, viewing eastward to show the Eighth Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Buildings shown across same are on the east side of the Ave. from 8th (right) to 9th (left) Streets. Note in the left foreground the foundation work for the new Womens Detention Prison (former site of the old Jefferson Market).
December 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A northward view on the east side of Sixth Ave., from West 8th Street.
May 1, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Similar to No. 1, but viewed northeastward on Christopher Street. On the extreme left is Greenwich AVe., and a corner of the new Women's Prison.
September 8, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

709321f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from between W. 8th and 9th Streets. The open area in the foreground is formed by the meeting of the aforementioned thoroughfares and Christopher Street and Greenwich Avenue. This is to be identified as "Village Square". View 3 shows the W. 8th Street station that was formerly located here. Intersection in the left foreground is W. 9th Street and
the bank is at the N. E. corner thereof.
March 8, 1939
March 10, 1939
January 17, 1930
P. L. perr

709322f-a.text:
(1)
Sixth Ave., at the S.W. corner of Greenwich Ave., as viewed from the 8th Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line, showing the automobile parking space, occupying that area. Also shown (left), are the rears of 3-story houses, facing on Gay Street, and bearing Nos. 13 to 19 (left to right. Adjoining same, and northward, is a 7-story warehouse (H, Lehlen & CoJw. facing on and bearing Nos. 12-10 Christopher Street. No. 8 Christopher Street, is the Pirates Den. Prominently shown (left to right) are the 12-story Heptagon Building (Nos. 147-153 Waverly Place), and a 17-story apartment house (No. 45 Christopher Street), between Waverly Place and Seventh Ave. South.
October 3, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2 & 3)
A set of 2 views showing the same location at an earlier date and
prior to clearance.
October 11, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.

709324f-a.text:
(1)
Sixth Ave., north from Greenwich Ave. On the left, appears the new Detention House for Women; formerly the site of Jefferson Market.
October 13, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg. #802
(2)
A view of the newly completed building, which replaced the old landmark that stood here for years. Shown is the Greenwich Ave.,
side.
October 13, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
Neg. #803
(3)
The same; from the street level. Note the Christmas Trees for
sale in the foreground.
December 24, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

709326f.text:
Sixth Ave, north from Greenwich Ave, showing 8th Street elevated station. Jefferson Market Police Court is seen in left foreground.
About 1890.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

Negative # 4068

709327f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue side of Jefferson Market.
August 20, 1927.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
Jefferson Market Court and Prison, from S.E. corner of Sixth
Avenue at 8th Street.
October 3, 1931.
P.L. Sperr,Photographer.

709328f-a.text:
Sixth Ave., west side, south from, but not including Greenwich Ave., showing the St. Joseph's R.C. Church, at the N.W. corner of Washington Place, and The Waverly, a 16-story apartment house, at the S.W. corner of Waverly Place. Also shown, (in the background), is a 12-story apartment building, at the S.W. corner of Cornelia Street, and a portion of the 8th Street Station
of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line (in foreground).
October 3, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

709331f-a.text:
(1)
Sixth Avenue at N.W. corner of Greenwich Avenue, showing bed of Minetta Creek and site of old Jefferson Market.
December 31, 1929.
P.L.Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
The same from Greenwich Avenue and viewing northward. Demolition in the foreground is for the new Detention House for Women.
1929.

709332f-a.text:
(1)
Jefferson Market from Sixth Avenue, south of 8th Street.
August 20, 1927.

(2)
Jefferson Market Sixth Avenue and 8th Street.

709338f-a.text: Jefferson Market Court House. About 1935. 6h Ave. & Greenwich Ave. Christopher and W.10th St.

710987f.text:
6 W. 8th St.

F.S. Lincoln
Photographer
114 East 32nd Street
New York City

190P1

710992f-a.text:
(1)
8th Street (formerly also known as Clinton Place), south side, west from 24 West 8th Street to Sixth Avenue. This is one of the principal shop and restaurant sections of Greenwich Village. Between 30 and 34 West 8th Street is the upper end of Macdougal Street. In the background is the Sixth Avenue Elevated Station. 28 West 8th Street, occupied by the Jumble Shop Restaurant, has in its time housed various notable people. James Fraser, the sculptor lived here; and the buffalo nickel was designed here by his wife, Laura Fraser. Edwin Arlington Robinson wrote some of his poetry at this address.
May 24, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, west from No. 20. Note the demolition at the S.W. corner of MacDougal Street. "Gonfarone's," a famous restaurant occupied the site for years. For further data upon same, see the New York Times of May 30, 1937.
June 1, 1937.
P.L. Sperr.

Neg. #553

(1)

710994f-a.text:
29 West 8th Street, and west, to Sixth Avenue, a close-up of the dry cleaners, restaurants, tea shops, art shops, and beauty parlors which make up this important Village thoroughfare. H. Behlen & Brothers, beyond the Sixth Avenue elevated, are in a building on the south side of Christopher Street.
May 24, 1933.
P.L. Sperr.
N2Neg. #486

West 8th Street, east from Sixth Ave., showing W.P.A. employees removing surface car tracks.

718774f-a.folder: Christopher Street & Greenwich Avenue, Manhattan, NY
718774f-a.text:
Christopher Street, west from Greenwich Avenue as viewed
from Sixth Avenue (under the "El").
Mr. Sperr reports the following: 'John Masefield, as a young man worked in Luke O'Connors Saloon which appears at the left (S.W. corner)
1900
J. J. Corell
P. L. Sperr
Nea ~4.

720152f-a.folder: Greenwich Avenue & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY
720152f-a.text:
Jefferson Market Courthouse and tower, seen from Greenwich Avenue,
east side, between Christopher and 10th Streets.
December 31, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

720153f-a.folder: Greenwich Avenue & Christopher Street, Manhattan, NY
720153f-a.text:
Greenwich Avenue, east side, north from Christopher Street to 30 Greenwich Avenue north of 10th Street, showing old Jefferson Market and the old jail. Subway construction is going on underhneath Greenwich Avenue.
August 20, 1927.
L. Sperr.

720156f-a.text:
Southeast on northeast side of Greenwich Avenue from 12th Street tn  its southeastern terminus at Sixth Avenue.
March 16, 1933.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.
